I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The road system of India can be grouped into four segments, viz., key national highway 
links under the jurisdiction of the National Highway Authority of India, other national highway 
links under the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways, state highways and roads under the 
state  public  works  departments  (PWDs),  and  rural  roads  under  the  Ministry  of  Rural 
Development. India is undertaking a major upgrading program for the sector that will take 10 
years at a total cost of $13 billion. The Government of India (GOI) has requested the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to provide a series of loans to cover part of this program. Given the 
potential scale of the lending, ADB has developed a programmatic approach whereby projects 
are be developed in a sequential and progressive manner while fulfilling ADB’s long-term policy 
objectives of fostering an enabling environment for the efficient and sustainable development of 
the road system so as to meet the needs of the public for increased mobility and efficient cargo 
movement. Specific interventions in the road sector will differ, since each of the four segments 
faces a different challenge.  
 
2.  For the state highways and roads segment, the medium- to long-term objectives of 
ADB’s  operations  are  to  strengthen  financing  capability  through  a  variety  of  mechanisms 
including state-level road funds and adopting a public-private partnership approach as well as 
reengineering the current institutional arrangements for road development and maintenance. 
The first state-level ADB intervention in the road sector was the Madhya Pradesh State Road 
Sector Development Program, which is being  processed this year. The Chhattisgarh State 
Roads Sector Development1 will be the second intervention, and technical assistance (TA) is 
required to help design both the infrastructure investment component and a policy reform and 
institutional strengthening component. A Fact-Finding Mission visited Chhattisgarh on 3-7 June 
2002 and reached an understanding with the Government of Chhattisgarh (GOC) as well as 
with  the  GOI  on  the  goals,  purpose,  scope,  implementation  arrangements,  cost,  financing 
arrangements, and terms of reference for the TA. The TA is included in the 2002 TA program for 
India.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  The State of Chhattisgarh was created following the bifurcation of the erstwhile Madhya 
Pradesh State effective 1 November 2000. The new state is rich in natural resources including 
bauxite, iron ore, and coal, and has a large forest cover, but is comparatively poor in terms of 
income levels and development indexes of the population. More than 40% of the population in 
the rural areas and about 26% in the urban areas live below the GOI-defined poverty line. The 
poor road network in the state has hampered its overall socioeconomic development and is thus 
a constraint in efforts to reduce poverty levels. The road network in the state, comprising about 
35,082 kilometers (km) — including 1,827 km of national highways, 3,611 km of state highways, 
2,118 km of district roads, and 27,526 km of village roads — is inadequate, as reflected in very 
low road density in Chhattisgarh compared with India as a whole. The total state road density 
per hundred square kilometers is 26.2%: 17.8% for metalled roads and 8.4% for unmetalled 
roads. This density is below the overall national average of 74.9% for all roads: 42.4% and 
32.5%  for  metalled  and  unmetalled  roads,  respectively.  About  31%  of  the  total  length  in

2  
Chhattisgarh is unmetalled. The inadequate nature of the road network is also seen in the lack 
of rural connectivity by all-weather roads for 40% of the villages in the state.   
 
4.  The state government envisages the development of the road sector in two north-south 
and  four  east-west  corridors,  improvement  of  connectivity  to  industrial  areas,  as  well  as 
enhanced rural road connectivity. The Chhattisgarh Infrastructure Development Corporation 
(CIDC) was established to promote infrastructure development in the state, including road 
infrastructure improvements using a public-private partnership modality, as it was felt that the 
decision-making  process  in  the  Chhattisgarh  PWD  was  very  slow  and  not  conducive  to 
attracting  private  sector  participation.  There  is  also  a  need  to  consider  the  policy  and 
institutional environment governing the road sector. The GOC has prepared a State Road Policy 
that emphasizes a sustainable, dedicated funding mechanism for road sector development and 
maintenance and the need for private sector participation. These policy objectives need to be 
complemented by an effective institutional mechanism so that they can be effectively and 
efficiently implemented. In particular, there is a need to put into place a realistic time-bound 
action plan that can help the GOC to operationalize the policies formulated. This will include 
identifying the constraints that can hinder implementation as well as the policy, institutional, and 
organizational changes needed for effective implementation. The major institution in the road 
sector is the Chhattisgarh PWD. 
 
5.  The PWD structure is bureaucratic and because of historical reasons input-focused, and 
should be reoriented to be output-focused. Staffing levels at professional levels are relatively 
low,  while  that  at  other  levels  is  quite  high  considering  that  all  works  including  routine 
maintenance works are contracted out. The number of employees in PWD is 8,745, of whom 
approximately 10% are temporary. Management of the road program is not linked to an overall 
optimal  resource  utilization  strategy.  The  financial  and  accounting  systems  need  to  be 
modernized. Although data collection on traffic and road conditions is carried out, the data 
management and utilization system needs to be modernized and computerized. Road planning 
and programming skills in the department could be enhanced by using modern computerized 
tools. PWD has outsourced technical designing to a great extent. Construction supervision is 
underresourced  and  process-oriented.  There  needs  to  be  put  into  place  modern  project 
management systems to help ensure better control of quality, progress, and cost. CIDC is a new 
organization designed to be very lean. At present it has only three professional staff, although 
more are being recruited. It outsources its work to the private sector. Considering the remit of 
the organization, there is a need to strengthen CIDC while maintaining its lean organizational 
structure and mode of operation, i.e., using private sector outsourcing extensively. 
 
6.  Overloading is also a serious problem aggravating the already poor road conditions and 
inadequate maintenance. It is estimated that over 80% of trucks are overloaded to some 
degree. This is actually a national problem, as the trucks involved are on interstate journeys, 
and there is a need to tackle it at the national level. The enforcement authorities in the state will 
need to be properly equipped to enhance enforcement of regulations concerning overloaded 
trucks in concert with efforts in neighboring states. Public transport services here are provided 
mainly by the private sector, although there is also a state-owned bus company. These services 
are inadequate in the outlying districts. The maximum fares that can be charged are regulated 
by the Chhattisgarh Transport Department. At present the maximum fare is set at Rs0.30/km. 
Goods transport is felt to be adequate in the state. The Transport Department does not control 
freight transport charges. At present roads account for 80% of total freight movement and 80% 
of passenger movement.

3
7.  However considerable analysis has already been carried out on the problems facing the 
state roads sector and possible ways to overcome them. The Strategic Options Study carried 
out by the World Bank, completed in 2000, carried out a comprehensive review of infrastructure 
and institutional needs in the state roads sector of erstwhile undivided Madhya Pradesh and it is 
a valuable resource on the problems facing the state roads sector in Chhattisgarh. Similarly the 
TA currently being carried out by ADB for the Madhya Pradesh state roads sector is another 
valuable  resource  that  can  be  utilized  for  this  current  TA.  This  is  because  the  solutions 
formulated for Madhya Pradesh are very relevant to Chhattisgarh, as the problems in the former 
are reflective of the situation in the latter as well, although the problems in Chhattisgarh are not 
as acute as those for Madhya Pradesh.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
8.  There will be two main components for this TA: the project preparation component and 
an institutional strengthening and policy reform component. It will be carried out in two phases. 
The outputs for Phase I will be (i) a master plan showing the road sector infrastructure needs for 
the next 10 years; (ii) prioritized investment needs for new roads, upgrading/major improvement 
of existing roads; (iii) feasibility studies, engineering studies, and preparation of bid documents 
for  100  km  of  major  upgrading  works  (henceforth  called  Phase  I  core  roads);  (iv)  initial 
environmental impact analysis and social impact analysis for the Phase I core roads; (v) 
resettlement plans for the Phase I core roads and resettlement framework for the overall sector 
development program; (vi) action plan for the institutional strengthening of key sector institutions 
focusing on the Chhattisgarh PWD; (vii) a private sector development plan to identify road 
projects in the Phase I core roads suitable to attract private sector financing or public-private 
partnerships; (viii) sector plans and an action plan to encourage the development of road 
transport services, e.g., public transport and freight transport, including reviewing relevant 
regulations;  (ix)  sector  plans  and  an  action  plan  to  improve  road  maintenance  including 
consideration  of  different  financing  mechanisms  and  reviewing  relevant  legislation  and 
enforcement of axle load and weight restriction regulations; and (x) sector plans and an action 
plan to improve road safety. The sector plans will set out the incremental steps necessary to 
achieve measurable progress, while the action plans will cover the implementation necessary to 
achieve the first steps of the sector plans. The action plans will thus cover the measures that 
could be implemented during the period to be covered by any possible investment project 
arising from this TA.  
 
9.  In Phase II the outputs will be (i) feasibility studies, engineering studies, and preparation 
of bid documents for 1000 km of major upgrading works and 500 km of district and rural roads 
under the jurisdiction of PWD (henceforth called Phase II core roads), with priority to be given to 
state roads that complement rural roads being constructed under the Pradhan Mantri Gram 
Sadak Yojna or Prime Minister’s Rural Road Program; (ii) initial environmental impact analysis 
and social impact analysis for the Phase II core roads; (iii) resettlement plans for the Phase II 
core roads using the resettlement framework developed in Phase I; and (iv) a private sector 
development plan to identify road projects in the Phase II core roads suitable to attract private 
sector financing or public-private partnerships.

4  
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  Traffic surveys, and road condition surveys need to be carried out to obtain latest traffic 
data and a road condition profile for the state. These need to be combined with other data on 
current and potential economic activities to estimate traffic patterns and volumes over the next 
10 years so that the road infrastructure expansion, upgrading, and maintenance needs over 
those years can be identified after considering the capacity and condition of the existing network 
to carry the estimated volumes. These have to be supplemented with some environmental and 
population surveys (including interview surveys) to formulate the initial environmental impact 
and social impact assessments for the five ranking projects in each of the categories of new 
projects, upgrading projects, and maintenance projects. Economic analysis of proposed projects 
will be necessary to prioritize them, while financial analysis will be necessary to identify projects 
for inclusion in the private sector development plan.  
 
11.  A detailed institutional analysis of PWD and CIDC will need to be carried out so that an 
institutional strengthening action plan can be formulated. The action plan will need to address 
the future institutional setup necessary for PWD to effectively manage the road sector; the 
staffing needs of PWD to carry out its road sector functions; institutional strengthening for the 
CIDC to play its role in road sector development; a labor rationalization plan to right-size PWD; 
recommendations for social safety nets to alleviate the negative impacts of labor rationalization; 
changes in PWD’s business processes to increase efficiency in internal resource utilization and 
management; and introduction of modern management and planning tools to enable PWD to 
carry  out  its  road  sector  management  functions  more  effectively,  including planning and 
programming  of  projects  for  new  investment  and  maintenance  as  well  as  more  effective 
methods of contracting out works and of monitoring contracts and contract management.  
 
12.  The activities that need to be carried out are data intensive, and adequate funds have 
been allocated for survey purposes. The time frame for the TA also takes into account the 
possibility that data might not be available in a timely fashion. The political will to push through 
the required reforms is a key factor, and the consultants will need to provide options how the 
reform process can be managed effectively during the implementation phase.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
13.  The cost of the TA is $1,000,000 equivalent, comprising $600,000 in foreign exchange 
costs and $400,000 equivalent in local currency costs. The entire foreign exchange cost of 
$600,000 and $200,000 equivalent of the local currency costs will be financed on a grant basis 
by the Government of the United Kingdom. The GOC will provide $200,000 equivalent for local 
currency  costs  in  the  form  of  services  and  facilities  including  counterpart  staff,  office 
accommodation, transport, and administrative resources. The budget includes provision for the 
travel costs of two government representatives to Manila for contract negotiations. Details of the 
cost estimates and financing plan are shown in Appendix 1.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  CIDC will be the Executing Agency for the TA, as it reports directly to the additional chief 
secretary and thus has greater bureaucratic clout to promote institutional reforms. A steering 
committee will be established; the GOC has identified the additional chief secretary-cum-finance 
secretary as chairperson of the steering committee, who will provide  policy guidance to the 
study. In addition to the chairperson, the steering committee will consist of representatives of 
the  Public  Works,  Transport,  Forest,  and  Industries  departments  and  CIDC.  The  steering

5
committee will meet monthly and the inception, draft final, and final reports of the consultants 
will need to be approved by it. The chairperson of the steering committee in turn has identified 
the secretary of public works to chair the two technical subcommittees that will be established to 
closely monitor the progress of the TA and report back to the steering committee. The first 
technical subcommittee will oversee the project preparatory component of the TA and, in 
addition  to  the  chairperson,  will  consist  of  senior  officers  of  PWD.  The  second  technical 
subcommittee will oversee the institutional development and policy reform component of the TA 
and, in addition to the chairperson, will consist of representatives of the Information Technology, 
Finance, and General Administration departments and CIDC. The technical subcommittees will 
discuss the working details of the study and provide overall coordination and support to the 
study. These subcommittees will meet at least once a month to consider the progress of the 
study. The GOC will also provide support in terms of office accommodation, counterpart staff, 
and transport free of charge. 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented in two segments: Part I including about 34 person-months of 
consulting services for preparation of the investment component, and Part II of about 6 person-
months for sector analysis and institutional improvement of PWD. Consulting services under 
Part  I  will  cover  tasks  for  both  Phase  I  and  Phase  II,  including  project  feasibility  study, 
preliminary  engineering  design,  economic  analysis  of  project  components,  social  and 
environmental impact assessments in accordance with requirements under ADB’s safeguard 
policies, and preparation of necessary procurement documents. The consultancy tasks for Part I 
will be implemented by an international firm in association with domestic consultants with 
expertise in (i) transport economics and traffic engineering (ii) highway engineering, (iii) geo-
tech and topographical survey, (iv) road structures, (v) social impact analysis and resettlement, 
(vi)  environmental  impact  assessment,  and  (vii)  contracts.  Consulting  services  of  about  3 
person- months of international consultants and 3 person-months of domestic consultants under 
Part II will be implemented by a consultant to be engaged separately with specialized expertise 
in road sector analysis, institutional development and strengthening, labor rationalization and 
public-private partnership in road sector.  Outline terms of reference for the consultants are 
attached as Appendix 2. The Summary Initial Poverty and Social Analysis (IPSA) is attached as 
Appendix 3.  
 
16.  The TA is expected to be carried out over 8 months starting in February 2003 and 
ending in October 2003. Advance action for the recruitment of consultants was approved by the 
President on 29 August 2002. Phase I will take 4 months and Phase II another 4 months. Three 
Tripartite Review Meetings will be held, one to consider the Inception Report, the second the 
Phase I draft final report and the last the Phase II draft final report. In addition there will be an 
ADB review mission one month after the inception report is approved. The consultants will also 
be required to organize two workshops to which all stakeholders will be invited. The first will 
focus on the infrastructure projects proposed, while the second will be on the institutional 
strengthening and policy reform component. The purpose of two workshops will be to give an 
opportunity to all stakeholders to review the findings of the TA and to give comments on them. 
The TA budget provides for these workshops and for the dissemination of information.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 to the Government 
of India to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of the United Kingdom for preparing 
the Chhattisgarh State Roads Sector Development, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

  OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.  Introduction 
18.  The Government of India has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide 
technical assistance (TA) for the formulation of projects suitable for financing by ADB in the 
Chhattisgarh State Roads Sector Development Program. There will be two main components 
for this TA: the project preparation component and an institutional strengthening and policy 
reform component. The objectives of the project preparatory component are to formulate a road 
infrastructure master plan identifying the needs for new roads, upgrading/major improvements 
needed for existing roads, and maintenance/minor improvement requirements of existing roads 
sufficient to cater to the socioeconomic development needs of Chhattisgarh State for the next 
10 years — suitable for consideration by ADB to be included as part of an investment loan for 
the sector; and to prepare in sufficient detail core projects that can be considered for investment 
loans, i.e., potential projects. The objectives of the institutional strengthening and policy reform 
component are to improve the efficiency of road sector institutions through the implementation 
of appropriate policy initiatives so that the road infrastructure asset base is sustained, and to 
ensure that the institutions involved in the road sector are able to perform their functions 
efficiently and effectively by developing a sector plan that will enable the Government of 
Chhattisgarh  (GOC)  to  achieve  the  medium-  and  long-term aims of fostering an enabling 
environment for efficient and sustainable development of the road system and reengineering the 
current institutions responsible for road development and maintenance. It is estimated that 10 
person-months of international and 30 person–months of domestic consulting services will be 
required.  
 
B.  Phase I Requirements 
 
1.  Part A  – Sector Analysis to be Done by Individual Consultants During 
Phase I  
19.  The activities required include but are not limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Identify  all  road-related  functions  currently  done  at  the  Chhattisgarh 
Public Works Department (PWD) and formulate a plan to delineate policy 
and  implementation  functions,  with  policy  functions  being  the  direct 
responsibility of the secretary of public works supported by PWD, and 
implementation functions being devolved to a dedicated road agency; 
analyze  and  identify  the  personnel  and  skill  levels  needed  for  the 
dedicated road agency; and carry out the preparatory work to set up the 
dedicated  road  agency  including  identifying  functions  and  formulating 
related organizational structure for both the headquarters of the dedicated 
road agency and its regional offices.  
 
(ii)  Prepare  an  institutional  development  plan  for  the  Chhattisgarh 
Infrastructure Development Corporation (CIDC) to effectively carry out its 
anticipated  work  load,  including  identifying  personnel  and  skill levels 
needed.

8  Appendix 3 
(iii)  Identify data requirements and formulate a plan to set up a data bank to 
support the dedicated road agency’s planning and operational functions. 
 
(iv)  Prepare a time-bound private sector development plan by identifying the 
activities (including design, construction, major periodic and rehabilitation 
maintenance, as well as quality control activities of the dedicated road 
agency and CIDC) that can be outsourced to private sector contracting 
and consulting firms. 
 
(v)  Review  and,  if  necessary,  suggest  improvements  to  guidelines  and 
operational procedures for transparent procurement of consulting and 
contracting services; identify financing requirements for maintenance of 
the  state  road  network;  identify  actual  allocations  spent  on  road 
maintenance  from  the  overall  road  maintenance  budget;  identify  all 
sources of road user revenues that are under the purview of GOC assess 
the possibility of increasing road user revenues under the purview of 
GOC and analyze the possibility of setting up a road maintenance trust 
fund with allocation from the GOC and road user revenue. 
 
(vi)  Based on the personnel requirements identified, prepare criteria for a 
compulsory retirement scheme (CRS) and voluntary retirement scheme 
(VRS); prepare guidelines for compensation for those taking the CRS and 
VRS; and estimate the amount that will be needed for a social safety net 
for those who will be taking the CRS and VRS. 
 
(vii)  Study the legal requirements to assess the adequacy of road legislation 
and  regulations,  and  to  enhance  the  enforcement  of  good  driving 
standards, including possible introduction of a demerit system for driving 
offences; study the legal requirements that can be implemented to check 
overloading  by  trucks;  and  formulate  an  action  plan  to  enhance  the 
enforcement  against  overloading  by  trucks,  including  identification  of 
equipment requirements. 
 
(viii)  Identify priority areas for modernizing the Road Transport Department 
and the State Traffic Police to enhance the enforcement of traffic and 
overloading offences. 
 
2.  Part B – To be Done by Consultant Firm during Phase I 
 
20.  The activities required include but are not limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Review  existing  plans  for  the  current  and  future  socioeconomic 
development of the state for agriculture, mining, industrial, and  tourism 
purposes  to  identify  required  corridors  for  road  infrastructure;  and 
estimate the likely traffic demand on each corridor for the next 10 years. 
 
(ii)  Review studies already carried out or currently being carried out by the 
GOC and, where necessary, supplement these studies for estimating the 
capacity  of  the  current  road  infrastructure  in  each  of  the  identified 
corridors  to  handle  the  estimated  traffic;  and  formulate  a  road 
infrastructure master plan that lists separately requirements for new road

construction,  major  improvement/upgrading  of  existing  roads,  and 
maintenance/minor upgrading of existing roads required to handle the 
estimated traffic volume. 
 
(iii)  Develop project selection criteria to identify priorities for investment for 
each of the three categories of investment needs identified above so that 
the projects listed in the master plan can be prioritized together with 
indicative dates of when they are needed to be in operation. 
 
(iv)  Carry out detailed technical and economic feasibility studies, engineering 
studies, and preparation of bid documents for 100 km of major upgrading 
roads (henceforth called the Phase I core roads); and review geological 
conditions, flood, watershed, and drainage design for major culverts and 
bridges required for the projects for which detailed feasibility studies are 
carried out. 
 
(v)  Carry out economic evaluation including economic internal rate of return 
(EIRR) and net present value (NPV) calculations of all projects included in 
the master plan according to ADB’s Guidelines for Economic Analysis of 
Projects by comparing the with– and without–project cases, taking into 
account all construction, operation, and maintenance costs together with 
changes in vehicle operating costs, time savings for passengers and 
freight, cost savings from reduced traffic accidents, benefits from possible 
generated traffic, and any other relevant quantifiable benefits and costs 
as well as calculating the EIRR and carrying out sensitivity analysis by 
appropriately  varying  key  parameters  that  underlie  the  estimates  of 
benefits, costs, implementation period, variation of diverted traffic, and a 
combination of these factors; and calculate switching values. 
 
(vi)  Carry  out  a  poverty  impact  study  on  the  impact  of  this  sector’s 
development on poverty reduction, and prepare an quantified assessment 
of  the  poverty  impact  ratio  of  the  core  projects  according  to  ADB’s 
Handbook  for  Integrating  Poverty  Impact  Analysis  in  the  Economic 
Analysis of Projects. 
 
(vii)  Prepare a resettlement plan for the Phase I core roads, and prepare the 
resettlement  framework  for  the  sector  as  well  as  an  initial  social 
assessment (ISA) in accordance with the relevant ADB guidelines. 
 
(viii)  Prepare an initial environmental examination (IEE) in accordance with 
ADB's Environmental Assessment Guidelines by taking into consideration 
the Government's guidelines on Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) 
for  the  Phase  I  core  roads;  assess  the  capacity  of  the  Government, 
particularly  the  Executing  Agency,  to  review  studies  and  implement 
environmental mitigation measures; recommend the review procedure for 
IEE of the follow up subprojects; and prepare environmental criteria for 
selection and appraisal of subprojects. 
 
(ix)  Prepare  a  private  sector  action  plan  by  identifying  projects  from  the 
master plan that are suitable for private sector involvement, either as 
privatized  projects  or  as  public-private  partnerships;  and  identify

complementary efforts by the Government that can make these projects 
attractive for private sector involvement. 
 
(x)  Design a suitable monitoring and evaluation system that can be used for 
monitoring project benefits and for postevaluation; and prepare a program 
and project frameworks including goals, purposes, outputs, and inputs in 
line with ADB requirements and using ADB format. 
 
(xi)  Prepare an action plan regarding measures to ensure compliance with 
ADB  policies  regarding  communicable  diseases  (including  HIV/AIDS), 
gender issues, and labor issues (including child labor). 
 
C.  Phase II Requirements 
 
21.  The activities required include but are not limited to the following: 
 
(i)  Carry out detailed technical and economic feasibility studies, engineering 
studies,  and  preparation  of  bid  documents  for  1,000  km  of  major 
upgrading works as well as 500 km of minor roads (this total of 1,500 km 
of roads being called the Phase II core roads). 
 
(ii)  Prepare a resettlement plan for the Phase II core roads, and prepare the 
resettlement framework for the sector as well as an ISA in accordance 
with ADB guidelines. 
 
(iii)  Prepare the IEE for the Phase II core roads in accordance with ADB’s 
Environmental  Assessment  Guidelines,  taking  into  consideration  the 
Government's guidelines on EIA. 
 
(iv)  Develop maintenance and design standards for different road classes and 
traffic levels, and introduce of HDM-4, appropriate bridge maintenance 
software. 
 
(v)  Identify  appropriate  software  for  planning  and  programming  highway 
network investment proposals, and install such software as a pilot project 
at  PWD  headquarters  including  preparing  operational  and  training 
manuals. 
 
(vi)  Formulate a plan to improve road safety, including setting up a road 
safety secretariat and preparing an action plan for it covering the first 3 
years. 
 
(vii)  Formulate a plan for improving road transport services.
